reviewText: A word about this disc's manufacturer.NOSTALGIA FAMILY VIDEO, formerly "Hollywood's Attic,"  is an unauthorized purveyor of classic era movies, vintage TV shows, serials, foreign films and more. A good portion of their catalog is public domain material.SYNOPSIS--Based on Arthur Miller's play, ALL MY SONS features Edward G. Robinson as an atypical villain: a machine shop owner who thinks that his illegalities were committed for his family's sake-- he's in total denial of all culpability. During WWII, Joe Keller (Robinson) knowingly sends out defective engine parts that ultimately cause the deaths of 21 American pilots. He allows his partner to take full blame, and the man is wrongly imprisoned.Burt Lancaster plays son Chris, just returned from war, who can't (or won't) believe what his father has done. Louisa Horton is Ann Deever, daughter of Joe's jailed partner. Ann was engaged to Chris's brother, now presumed dead in battle. Mady Christians is the mother who steadfastly and irrationally refuses to accept the death of her son.Chris and Ann bond, fall in love and become engaged, which angers Ann's brother George (Howard Duff), for he knows the truth about Joe Keller's crimes. When Chris visits Herbert Deever (Frank Conroy) in jail, Deever convinces Chris of his innocence. Next comes a dramatic showdown of words between Chris and his father.Although not issued by the studio on DVD (as of 12/08), there are still limited numbers of VHS copies ofALL MY SONSavailable (at premium prices).A year after this picture, Edward G. Robinson was given a "Best Actor" award at the Cannes Film Festival for the superb film noir, HOUSE OF STRANGERS.  (VHS edition)  (DVD edition)Burt Lancaster's sole Oscar win was for the lead in ELMER GANTRY (1960)  (VHS edition)  (DVD edition)Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(7.5) All My Sons (1948) - Edward G. Robinson/Burt Lancaster/Mady Christians/Louisa Hortins/Howard Duff/Frank Conroy/Arlene Francis/Harry Morgan

reviewText: Wow.  Caught this, by chance, just surfing cable early one morning on Turner Classic Movies.  Never heard of it.  This films grabs you by the collar from frame one and doesn't let go. What is this film? Sneak away to the Net.  Written by Arthur Miller who wrote Death of a Salesman. Script, direction, acting, black and white cinematography - all outstanding. I won't go into the plot synopsis, but a young Burt Lancaster is terrific in it, as are the recognizable women in the cast. But the stand-out here is the performance of Edward G. Robinson, who's simply perfect. Man - could that guy act. All My Sons is a powerful philosophic morality play that couldn't have been executed any better.  Do yourself a favor and rent it, put it in your Netflix queue, or buy it here on Amazon. If anything, to remind yourself of the power of films in the age of lame comic book adaptations, sequels, and CGI dreck.

reviewText: ALL MY SONS is recorded in two versions for the home theater.  Both are kind of hard to find, but worth the hunt whether on the internet or a local library loan.By far the best is the rare 1946 film starring Edward G. Robinson and Burt Lancaster.  Somewhat compressed from Miller's play, with a few scenes slightly rearranged, this deeply engaging drama features Robinson in a superb, empathetic and finally tragic performance as family patriarch Joe Keller who ran a successful company that turned out defective parts that the death of many American fighting in WW II.  But Keller escaped punishment and framed his partner Herbert Deever, who was sent to prison, while Keller himself went on to make a fortune.  But it's all come home now.  Larry, one of Keller's sons is missing in action and another, Chris (Burt Lancaster) wants to marry Larry's sweetheart who is also Deever's daughter.  We see Keller's apparently successful life slowly unravel as the lies of the past are brought into the light of the present.Arthur Miller (1915 - 2005) first started writing ALL MY SONS, he said the play would either be the start or the end of his career as a playwright.  When his previous attempt, THE MAN WHO HAD ALL THE LUCK (1944), his first and only play, was produced on Broadway, it lasted only four performances.  It was an unmitigated disaster, and almost discouraged Miller from trying to write another, but he knew the only guarantee of failure is to quit.  So he gave himself one more try.Three years later, ALL MY SONS won New York Drama Critics' Circle Award as best play of 1947, launching Miller into theatrical stardom as the most famous playwright of the 2oth Century - to say nothing of becoming Marilyn Monroe's husband.
summary: ARTHUR MILLER'S FIRST BIG SUCCESS STILL WRENCHES

reviewText: The company that made the DVD did an excellent job.  The graphics on the front cover and the photos on the back were well chosen.  I'd deal with this vendor again.  The movie? One of the best EVER and a great adaptation of Arthur Miller's most compelling play.  The cast? Outstanding, powerful performances from Burt Lancaster, Edward G. Robinson, and Howard Duff.
summary: A Great Movie Finally Available on DVD

reviewText: This is one of the most important American movies ever made. It dramatizes how unscrupulous arms-manufacturers sold defective weapons to the US. military during World War Two, which resulted in the needless deaths of thousands of American GIs. This fact is well-documented in DOD records unclassified after the war.Arthur Miller's play was a hit on Broadway, but during the McCarthy Era the Republican House UnAmerican Activities Committee tried to prevent it from being produced as a movie. Failing that, they tried to get it banned. Failing that, writer Arthur Miller and star Edward G. Robinson were both accused of being communists and blacklisted. Their careers were ruined for decades after.All My Sons is one of the most powerful movies you'll ever see.Except that now you can't see it.
summary: Important American film withheld from public
